description: Leakage errors occur when a qubit transitions from the computational subspace (|0⟩, |1⟩) to higher energy levels (|2⟩, |3⟩, ...) of the physical system. Unlike erasure, leakage is typically not heralded — the qubit remains in the system but occupies a state outside the intended two-level subspace, and subsequent gates may behave unpredictably.

Leakage is particularly problematic in superconducting transmon qubits, where the weak anharmonicity (~200–300 MHz) means that drive pulses intended for the 0→1 transition can excite the 1→2 transition. Multi-qubit gates (e.g., cross-resonance, iSWAP) are especially susceptible to leakage because they involve strong driving fields.

Once a qubit has leaked, it can propagate errors to neighboring qubits through entangling gates, causing correlated failures that are difficult to diagnose. Leakage reduction units (LRUs) — reset operations that return leaked qubits to the computational subspace — are a common hardware-level mitigation.

diagrams.caption: Energy level structure showing leakage: the computational subspace uses the |0⟩↔|1⟩ transition (ω₀₁), but anharmonicity (ω₁₂ ≠ ω₀₁) allows unwanted excitation to higher levels |2⟩, |3⟩, etc.

quantum_channel.kraus_form: \mathcal{E}(\rho) = \sum_k K_k \rho K_k^\dagger \quad \text{where } K_k \text{ act on extended Hilbert space } \{|0\rangle, |1\rangle, |2\rangle, \ldots\}

properties.Parameters: Leakage rate per gate; depends on anharmonicity and drive parameters
properties.Heralded: No — leakage is generally not directly detectable without additional measurement
properties.Propagation: Leaked qubits can spread errors through subsequent entangling gates

physical_examples: Transmon qubits excited to the |2⟩ state by off-resonant driving
Cross-resonance gates inducing 1→2 transitions in spectator qubits
Parametric gates in tunable couplers causing multi-level transitions
Raman transitions in trapped ions populating unintended atomic levels
qem_considerations: Dynamical decoupling can suppress leakage by averaging out off-resonant driving effects
Symmetry verification can detect some leakage events via conserved quantity violations
Leakage reduction units (LRUs) actively reset leaked qubits before errors propagate
Leakage complicates Pauli noise assumptions used by PEC and ZNE; twirling may not fully convert leakage to Pauli noise
